chunk_summary: Follow-up for typhoid and enteric fever focuses on recovery, relapse prevention, and carrier management, emphasizing full antibiotic courses, targeted stool cultures, and public health measures for confirmed carriers.
learning_objectives: Understand the clinical follow-up process for typhoid and enteric fever, including relapse detection and prevention.
Learn the management strategies for relapse and chronic Salmonella carriage in pediatric and adolescent patients.
Identify public health measures to reduce household and community transmission during recovery.
key_facts: Relapse typically occurs within 1–3 weeks after completing therapy and presents with milder symptoms.
Persistent Salmonella shedding in stool is transient during convalescence; chronic carriage is rare in children.
Routine stool cultures are not recommended for well pediatric patients but may be targeted in outbreaks or food handlers.
Children can return to school once afebrile, clinically well, and able to participate normally.
Strict hand hygiene and safe water practices are essential to reduce household transmission during recovery.
reference_quote: Relapse should be managed as a new episode: obtain culture if possible, review prior adherence and antibiotic choice, and treat with a full course guided by susceptibility. (Source: StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf)
document_key_topics: Salmonella carrier state and public health measures
